titleStmt.title: An adab to Dagan (?) for I&c;me-Dagan (I&c;me-Dagan U) -- an English prose translation

publicationStmt.distributor: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature

address.addrLine: The Oriental Institute, University of Oxford, Pusey Lane, Oxford OX1 2LE, UK, email etcsl@orinst.ox.ac.uk, http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk

seriesStmt.p: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature aims to make accessible over 400 literary works composed in the Sumerian language in ancient Mesopotamia during the late third and early second millennia BC. The works are in Sumerian composite transliteration and English prose translation with bibliographical information on each composition.

sourceDesc.p: Sources are listed in the header of the composite text

lg.p:
In the E-kur, the house &X;&X;. The great gods &X;&X; to your upraised hands. &X;&X; holy lap for your exceedingly pleasant life. &X;&X; for its good reign &X;&X;. I&c;me-Dagan, the son of Enlil &X;&X;. &X;&X; joy (?) in the Egal-ma&h;, your ladylike house. &X;&X; the prince &X;&X; me&c; tree with shining branches &X;&X;. &X;&X; to make his life pleasant &X;&X; I&c;me-Dagan &X;&X;. &X;&X; holy &X;&X; the child of An &X;&X;.
&X;&X; brick-built E-kur &X;&X;.
Dagan, you have &X;&X; the shepherd I&c;me-Dagan, the son of Enlil, with a royal garment.

The lofty lord, &X;&X; the divine powers of heaven and the divine powers of the earth; Dagan, the august lord, &X;&X; the divine powers of heaven and the divine powers of the earth. He has chosen I&c;me-Dagan in the Land, he &X;&X;.

trailer.p: An adab of Dagan (?). lines 19 and 20 are written as one line in source
